section_purpose: To analyze variable embeddings from GNNs to explain how they learn to solve SAT problems, showing that embeddings cluster into distinct groups corresponding to optimal assignments.
key_points: Variable embeddings form distinct clusters that correspond to optimal variable assignments.
Embeddings start randomly distributed and gradually organize into two clusters through message passing iterations.
Applying k-means clustering with k=2 to these embeddings can recover approximate optimal solutions.
This clustering behavior occurs even in networks trained only to predict satisfiability status.

algorithms: Dimensionality reduction (McInnes et al. [2018], likely UMAP) for visualization

dependencies: Section 4.2 Architecture Variants (implied for GNN structure)
reproducibility_notes: Use of dimensionality reduction method (e.g., UMAP) to visualize embeddings
Application of k-means clustering with k=2 to embeddings for assignment recovery
Extraction of variable embeddings from trained GNN models
